questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. A CT scan reveals a mass located in the middle mediastinum. Based on its location, what is the most common type of tumor likely to be found in this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pericardial cyst

 

  • The most common tumor or lesion in the middle mediastinum is a cyst, particularly a pericardial cyst. 
  • These are benign, fluid-filled structures that are often asymptomatic but may be discovered incidentally during imaging for other conditions. 
  • They are associated with the middle mediastinal compartment due to their proximity to the heart and great vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymoma: The most common tumor in the anterior mediastinum, not the middle mediastinum. Thymomas are often associated with myasthenia gravis and other paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Option C. Neurogenic tumor: The most common tumor in the posterior mediastinum, not the middle mediastinum. These tumors arise from nerve roots or peripheral nerves.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: Lymphomas can occur in all three compartments of the mediastinum but are not the most common tumor specifically associated with the middle mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common tumor or lesion in the middle mediastinum is a cyst, such as a pericardial cyst. 
  • Understanding the distribution of mediastinal masses by compartment is critical for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about teduglutide?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a GLP-2 agonist

 

  • Teduglutide is a GLP-2 agonist that mimics the action of the naturally occurring hormone glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2).
  • GLP-2 is involved in promoting intestinal growth and improving nutrient absorption.
  • Teduglutide is used in the management of conditions like short bowel syndrome to enhance intestinal adaptation and improve nutrient absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is effective orally: Teduglutide is not effective orally. It is administered via subcutaneous injection because it is a peptide that would be degraded in the gastrointestinal tract if taken orally.

 

Option C. It is a pancreatic enzyme: Teduglutide is not a pancreatic enzyme. It is a GLP-2 agonist that works by improving the function and adaptation of the small intestine, not by supplementing pancreatic enzymes.

 

Option D. It is shorter acting because of degradation by dipeptidylpeptidase 4: Teduglutide is not significantly degraded by dipeptidylpeptidase 4 (DPP-4). It has a longer half-life compared to endogenous GLP-2 due to modifications that make it resistant to degradation, which is why it is administered less frequently than other peptides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TEDUGLUTIDE:

 

  • It is a recombinant analog of human glucagon like peptide 2.
  • It is used for the treatment of adults with short bowel syndrome.
  • It works by promoting mucosal growth and possibly restoring gastric emptying and secretion.
  • It is given by subcutaneous route.
  • It is long acting drug because it is resistant to degradation by DPP-4

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is undergoing evaluation for tumor surveillance due to the increased risk of malignancies associated with this condition. Tumors commonly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemangioblastoma

 

  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with an increased risk of embryonal tumors, particularly Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, and adrenal carcinoma. 
  • These tumors arise due to abnormal regulation of growth caused by alterations in imprinted genes.
  • Hemangioblastoma is associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, not Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilms tumor: One of the most common tumors in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Option B. Hepatoblastoma: Frequently associated with this syndrome, especially in early childhood.

 

Option C. Adrenal carcinoma: Another malignancy seen in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, and adrenal carcinoma, but not hemangioblastoma. 
  • Regular tumor surveillance is crucial in affected children.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolites is specifically produced during the beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propionyl CoA

 

  • Beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids proceeds similarly to that of even-chain fatty acids, with the key difference occurring during the final cycle. 
  • The breakdown of odd-chain fatty acids produces propionyl CoA, a three-carbon compound, as the terminal product instead of acetyl CoA. 
  • Propionyl CoA is then converted to succinyl CoA, an intermediate of the citric acid cycle, through a multi-step process involving carboxylation and rearrangement.
  • Odd-chain fatty acids are metabolically significant because their products can enter gluconeogenesis via the citric acid cycle, allowing for glucose production—a pathway not available for even-chain fatty acids, which exclusively produce acetyl CoA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malonyl CoA: Malonyl CoA is not a product of beta-oxidation. It is a key intermediate in fatty acid synthesis and functions as an inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT1), thus regulating fatty acid entry into mitochondria for beta-oxidation.

 

Option C. Succinyl CoA: Although succinyl CoA is ultimately derived from propionyl CoA during the metabolism of odd-chain fatty acids, it is not a direct product of beta-oxidation. The conversion of propionyl CoA to succinyl CoA requires several enzymatic steps involving propionyl CoA carboxylase and methylmalonyl CoA mutase.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA: Acetyl CoA is a primary product of beta-oxidation of even-chain fatty acids, but in odd-chain fatty acids, the final cycle produces propionyl CoA instead of acetyl CoA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids produces propionyl CoA as the final product, which is converted into succinyl CoA and can enter the citric acid cycle for gluconeogenesis. 
  • This distinguishes odd-chain fatty acid metabolism from even-chain fatty acid oxidation.

questions.text: A full-term baby was born 14 hours ago. As the pediatrician on duty, you are called to assess the newborn for a routine check-up. On examination, the baby appears well, with no apparent abnormalities. The mother, however, expresses concern as the baby has not yet passed any stool or urine. She asks for clarification on what is considered the normal time frame for a newborn to pass urine and meconium. What would be the appropriate response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours

 

  • In a healthy, full-term newborn, it is expected for the first urine to be passed within 24 hours after birth and for the first meconium to be passed within 48 hours. 
  • Delays beyond this time frame could indicate underlying conditions, such as congenital urinary tract obstruction, meconium ileus, or other gastrointestinal issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine within 12 hours and meconium within 24 hours: While it is possible for some newborns to pass urine and meconium earlier than the standard time frame, the average expected time for urine and meconium is within 24 and 48 hours, respectively.

 

Option C. Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 12 hours: Meconium passage within 12 hours may occur, but the upper limit is typically considered 48 hours.

 

Option D. Urine within 48 hours and meconium within 24 hours: Delayed urine passage beyond 24 hours is not typical and warrants further investigation for potential urinary tract issues.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • A healthy, full-term newborn is expected to pass urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours after birth. 
  • Delays beyond these time frames may indicate underlying pathologies and require medical evaluation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of yellow skin and abdominal discomfort. He is currently being treated for tinea corporis with itraconazole and recently completed a course of erythromycin for pneumonia. Laboratory findings are as follows. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythromycin adverse effect

 

  • This patient’s symptoms of jaundice and abdominal discomfort, combined with elevated liver enzymes, are consistent with drug-induced liver injury (DILI). 
  • Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is a known cause of DILI due to its hepatotoxic effects. 
  • The temporal association between erythromycin use and the onset of symptoms supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcoholic hepatitis: Incorrect, While alcoholic hepatitis can cause elevated liver enzymes, there is no history of alcohol use or associated findings such as macrocytosis or significant AST:ALT >2 ratio.

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica infection: Incorrect, Amoebic liver abscess typically presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and significantly elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, which are not observed here.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B: Incorrect, The patient has a negative HBsAg and anti-hepatitis B core antigen, ruling out active hepatitis B infection. The positive anti-HBsAg indicates prior vaccination or resolved infection.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug-induced liver injury is a common cause of hepatotoxicity. Erythromycin and other macrolides can cause cholestatic or hepatocellular liver injury. 
  • A careful medication history is essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with signs of drug toxicity. Laboratory analysis suggests impaired detoxification of xenobiotics involving phase 1 hydroxylation reactions. These reactions require monooxygenase/cytochrome P-450 along with which of the following cofactors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH

 

  • Phase 1 reactions in the detoxification of xenobiotics, such as hydroxylation, are mediated by the cytochrome P-450 monooxygenase system. 
  • This system introduces a hydroxyl group into lipophilic molecules to increase their polarity, aiding in their excretion. 
  • The P-450 system is located in the endoplasmic reticulum and requires NADPH as an electron donor to reduce the cytochrome P-450 enzyme. 
  • NADPH is generated primarily through the pentose phosphate pathway and transfers electrons via NADPH-cytochrome P450 reductase to facilitate hydroxylation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NADH: NADH is involved in energy metabolism and the electron transport chain but is not the primary electron donor for cytochrome P-450 in phase 1 hydroxylation reactions. NADPH, not NADH, is the correct cofactor.

 

Option C. FADH2: FADH2 is a flavin adenine dinucleotide that transfers electrons in the electron transport chain and specific dehydrogenase reactions. However, it does not directly participate in the cytochrome P-450 hydroxylation process.

 

Option D. FAD: FAD is a cofactor in various oxidoreductase enzymes but is not used by the cytochrome P-450 system for xenobiotic detoxification. The system relies specifically on NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phase 1 detoxification reactions involving hydroxylation by cytochrome P-450 require NADPH as an essential electron donor to facilitate the enzymatic process.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss over the past three months. He also reports early satiety. Physical examination reveals significant splenomegaly. Laboratory findings show anemia and a leukoerythroblastic blood picture. A peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myelofibrosis

 

  • The clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and peripheral blood smear are classic for myelofibrosis, a chronic myeloproliferative disorder characterized by:
    1. Bone marrow fibrosis: Progressive replacement of normal bone marrow with fibrous tissue.
    2. Extramedullary hematopoiesis: Since the bone marrow is fibrotic, hematopoiesis shifts to extramedullary sites such as the spleen and liver, causing significant splenomegaly.
    3. Leukoerythroblastic blood picture: Immature erythroid and myeloid precursors are seen in peripheral blood because of extramedullary hematopoiesis.
    4. Tear-drop cells (dacrocytes): Red blood cells are mechanically deformed as they pass through the fibrotic marrow or spleen.
  • The patient's symptoms (fatigue, night sweats, weight loss) are consistent with systemic symptoms due to bone marrow failure. 
  • Early satiety occurs due to splenic enlargement compressing the stomach.

 

Key diagnostic features:

 

  • Peripheral smear: Tear-drop cells and immature myeloid and erythroid precursors.
  • Clinical findings: Splenomegaly and systemic symptoms.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Fibrosis confirmed with reticulin staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML typically presents with symptoms of bone marrow failure (severe anemia, infections, and bleeding). Peripheral blood smear shows blasts, not the tear-drop cells or leukoerythroblastic picture seen in myelofibrosis.

 

Option C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): CLL primarily involves mature lymphocyte proliferation and is associated with lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows small, mature lymphocytes and smudge cells but does not feature tear-drop cells or a leukoerythroblastic picture.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency: G6PD deficiency causes hemolytic anemia, often triggered by oxidative stress (e.g., infections, certain drugs). Peripheral smear typically shows Heinz bodies and bite cells, not tear-drop cells or leukoerythroblastic findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myelofibrosis is characterized by bone marrow fibrosis leading to a leukoerythroblastic blood picture, tear-drop cells, splenomegaly, and symptoms of bone marrow failure.

questions.text: All of these are correctly matched boundaries of the femoral ring except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral- Conjoint tendon

 

  • The femoral canal is the space exploited by a femoral hernia. 
  • The boundaries of the femoral canal are the femoral vein laterally, the inguinal ligament anteriorly, the pelvic bone covered by the iliopectineal ligament (Astley Cooper’s) posteriorly and the lacunar ligament (Gimbernat’s) medially. 
  • This is a strong curved ligament with a sharp unyielding edge that impedes reduction of a femoral hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior - Inguinal ligament: This is correct. The inguinal ligament forms the superior border of the femoral canal.

 

Option B. Inferior - Pecten pubis: The pecten pubis, or pectineal line of the pubic bone, contributes to the inferior border of the femoral canal.

 

Option C: Medial - Lacunar ligament - The lacunar ligament, also known as Gimbernat's ligament, forms the medial border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The conjoint tendon does not form the lateral border of the femoral ring; rather, the femoral vein occupies this position.

Pulmonary embolism with right heart strain

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, who delivered her first child 3 months ago, presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in her legs. She denies any prior history of cardiovascular disease or hypertension during pregnancy. On physical examination, there is jugular venous distension, bilateral pitting edema, and an S3 gallop. Chest X-ray is shown below.

 

 

Echocardiography shows global hypokinesis and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. Laboratory findings include:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM)

 

  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of heart failure occurring in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months postpartum. 
  • It is characterized by new-onset left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF <45%) without a pre-existing cause. 
  • The patient’s symptoms of heart failure, echocardiographic findings, and elevated BNP levels strongly indicate PPCM, especially given her postpartum status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to viral myocarditis: Incorrect, Viral myocarditis can mimic PPCM, but the patient has no preceding viral illness or evidence of inflammatory markers.

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism with right heart strain: Incorrect, Pulmonary embolism typically causes acute onset dyspnea, chest pain, and right heart strain on echocardiography. This patient has left ventricular dysfunction, which is not consistent with a pulmonary embolism.

 

Option D. Postpartum pre-eclampsia with heart failure: Incorrect, Pre-eclampsia can cause heart failure, but this patient has no history of hypertension during pregnancy and normal blood pressure, which makes this less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a diagnosis of exclusion characterized by heart failure in the peripartum period with no identifiable cause. 
  • Elevated BNP, reduced ejection fraction, and the timing of symptoms are crucial for diagnosis. 
  • Early recognition and management are vital to improving outcomes.

questions.text: A 48-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. She denies pain or other symptoms. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histopathological examination of curettage

 

  • In postmenopausal women presenting with vaginal bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasound raises concern for endometrial pathology, including hyperplasia or carcinoma. 
  • The next best step in management is histopathological examination of the endometrium, which can be achieved through endometrial biopsy or curettage. 
  • This approach allows definitive diagnosis by evaluating the endometrial tissue for malignancy or pre-malignant changes.
  • In this case, the patient’s endometrial thickness of 6 mm exceeds the threshold of concern, making histopathological examination essential for excluding serious conditions like endometrial cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start tamoxifen therapy: Tamoxifen is associated with an increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma due to its partial agonist effect on the endometrium. It is not a treatment for postmenopausal bleeding and would not be appropriate without a tissue diagnosis. Initiating tamoxifen in this context could exacerbate a pre-existing endometrial pathology.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment for confirmed endometrial carcinoma or other significant pathologies. However, it is not a first-line diagnostic step. A tissue diagnosis must be obtained through histopathological examination before considering this invasive surgical intervention.

 

Option D. Perform saline infusion sonohysterography: While saline infusion sonohysterography is a useful tool to evaluate endometrial pathology in certain cases, it is not a replacement for tissue diagnosis. In a patient with postmenopausal bleeding and increased endometrial thickness, histopathological examination remains the gold standard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In postmenopausal women with vaginal bleeding and an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasound, the next best step is histopathological examination of the endometrium via biopsy or curettage. 
  • This step is crucial for ruling out or diagnosing endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of glaucoma is prescribed acetazolamide to help reduce intraocular pressure. When explaining the mechanism of action of acetazolamide, which of the following best describes how it interacts with carbonic anhydrase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

  • Acetazolamide, along with other drugs like dorzolamide and brinzolamide, is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. 
  • Carbonic anhydrase plays an important role in the formation of aqueous humor in the eye, as well as in various other physiological processes, such as the regulation of acid-base balance and fluid balance.
  • Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase through a non-competitive mechanism, meaning it binds to the enzyme at a site distinct from the active site, altering the enzyme's activity. 
  • This inhibition is reversible, meaning that acetazolamide does not permanently inactivate the enzyme. 
  • This reversible, non-competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the formation of bicarbonate ions, which reduces the production of aqueous humor and thus lowers intraocular pressure in conditions like glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor: This option is incorrect. While acetazolamide does have a reversible effect on carbonic anhydrase, its inhibition is non-competitive, not competitive. A competitive inhibitor binds to the active site of the enzyme, competing with the substrate. However, acetazolamide binds elsewhere on the enzyme, causing a change in the enzyme's shape and activity.

 

Option C. Competitive and irreversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor: This is incorrect. Acetazolamide is not competitive (it is non-competitive) and is also reversible, not irreversible. Irreversible inhibitors permanently bind to and inactivate the enzyme, which is not the case for acetazolamide.

 

Option D. Non-competitive and irreversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor: This option is incorrect. While acetazolamide's inhibition is non-competitive, it is reversible, not irreversible. This distinction is important because reversible inhibition allows for the recovery of enzyme activity once the drug is cleared from the system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acetazolamide is a non-competitive, reversible inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase, which reduces the formation of aqueous humor and is used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions such as glaucoma.

Rapid reduction in factor X levels

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with atrial fibrillation is started on warfarin for stroke prevention. On 2nd day, he presents with skin necrosis and signs of hypercoagulability. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the development of this patient's symptoms within 2 days of initiating warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Protein C and S deficiency exacerbated by warfarin

 

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis and hypercoagulability typically occur in the initial days after initiating therapy, particularly in patients with a deficiency of protein C or S, which are natural anticoagulants. 
  • Warfarin initially inhibits the synthesis of both procoagulant and anticoagulant vitamin K-dependent proteins, but protein C and S have a shorter half-life. 
  • This leads to a temporary prothrombotic state (hypercoagulability) before the procoagulant proteins are reduced, and this can trigger skin necrosis due to clot formation in the small vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin-induced factor V deficiency: Factor V deficiency is not associated with warfarin-induced skin necrosis or hypercoagulability. The problem is related to the depletion of protein C and S, not factor V.

 

Option C. Depletion of thrombomodulin: While thrombomodulin plays a role in the coagulation cascade, it is not specifically involved in warfarin-induced skin necrosis or hypercoagulability. The main issue here is the protein C and S deficiency.

 

Option D. Rapid reduction in factor X levels: A reduction in factor X would cause bleeding, not a hypercoagulable state. The issue in warfarin therapy is the imbalance in protein C and S levels that leads to initial hypercoagulability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is typically due to protein C and S deficiencies, leading to a hypercoagulable state early in therapy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of yellowing of the skin and eyes. He denies other symptoms and recalls a similar episode three years ago. Recently, he has noticed dark urine. Laboratory tests reveal a serum bilirubin level of 4.6 mg/dL, predominantly conjugated. Serum AST and ALT levels are within normal limits. A liver biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dubin-Johnson syndrome

 

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive condition characterized by a defect in the hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile. 
  • This results in chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which is usually asymptomatic but may present with mild jaundice triggered by stress, illness, or fasting.
  • Histological hallmark: The presence of darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, as seen in the biopsy, is characteristic of Dubin-Johnson syndrome. The pigment is thought to be a derivative of epinephrine metabolites that accumulate in lysosomes.
  • Patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome typically have normal liver enzyme levels (AST, ALT, and alkaline phosphatase), distinguishing it from other liver disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome also causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but it lacks the dark pigmentation of hepatocytes seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Additionally, patients with Rotor syndrome do not have any hepatic histological abnormalities on biopsy.

 

Option C. Gilbert syndrome: Gilbert syndrome is characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme uridine diphosphate-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1). It does not cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or histological abnormalities.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: Crigler-Najjar syndrome involves severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to an inherited deficiency of UGT1A1. It does not cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or liver pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy reveals darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, a hallmark of the condition.

questions.text: A hospital microbiology laboratory is conducting tests to evaluate the germicidal power of a new disinfectant. The disinfectant’s germicidal efficacy is compared to phenol using the Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC). The laboratory uses Salmonella typhi as the test organism for this evaluation. If the RWC of the disinfectant is reported as RWC = 10, what does this imply about the disinfectant’s potency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The disinfectant is 10 times more potent than phenol.

 

  • The Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC), also known as the Carbolic Acid Coefficient, is used to represent the germicidal power of a disinfectant.
  • It compares the effectiveness of a disinfectant to phenol, which is used as a standard (RWC = 1). 
  • An RWC of 10 means the disinfectant is 10 times more potent than phenol. 
  • Thus, it takes a much smaller concentration of this disinfectant to achieve the same germicidal effect as phenol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disinfectant is equally potent as phenol: This is incorrect because an RWC of 1 would indicate the disinfectant is equally potent to phenol, but the RWC in this case is 10, meaning it is more potent than phenol.

 

Option B. The disinfectant is 10 times less potent than phenol: This is incorrect. An RWC greater than 1 indicates the disinfectant is more potent than phenol, not less.

 

Option D. The disinfectant is ineffective in the presence of organic matter: This is incorrect because it refers to a limitation of the RWC test in the presence of organic matter, but it does not explain the RWC result of 10. The effectiveness of the disinfectant is measured in comparison to phenol under standard conditions (without considering organic matter).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC) is used to compare the germicidal power of a disinfectant to phenol, with an RWC of 10 indicating that the disinfectant is 10 times more potent than phenol.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Tungiasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ecto parasite skin infection

 

  • Tungiasis is an ectoparasitic skin infection caused by the flea Tunga penetrans, which burrows into the skin, primarily on the feet and toes. 
  • The female flea, after penetrating the skin, forms a burrow to lay her eggs. 
  • This causes significant irritation, itching, and sometimes ulceration at the site. 
  • This condition is common in travelers returning from regions such as Latin America (particularly Brazil) and Sub-Saharan Africa where the parasite is endemic. 
  • Therefore, Tungiasis is classified as an ectoparasitic infection because the parasite lives and feeds on the outer surface of the body, in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ecto parasite intestinal infection: This is incorrect because ectoparasites are typically found on the surface of the body, such as on the skin. An intestinal infection would be caused by an endoparasite, not an ectoparasite like Tunga penetrans.

 

Option C. Endo parasite skin infection: This is incorrect because endo parasites live inside the body, typically in the intestines or other internal organs. Tungiasis is caused by an ectoparasite that lives on the skin, not inside the body.

 

Option D. Endo parasite intestinal infection: This is incorrect because Tungiasis is not caused by an intestinal parasite, but by an ectoparasite (Tunga penetrans), which affects the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tungiasis is an ectoparasitic skin infection caused by the flea Tunga penetrans.
  • It presents with burrowing lesions and is commonly seen in travelers returning from Latin America and Sub-Saharan Africa.

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new antihypertensive medication in reducing blood pressure. The study is performed in a highly controlled hospital environment with a specific population of middle-aged patients who have mild hypertension and no other comorbidities. The researchers report that the medication significantly reduces blood pressure in the study participants. However, there is concern among the medical community about whether these results will be applicable to patients with different characteristics, such as older adults, patients with comorbid conditions, or those living in community settings. Which of the following best describes the type of validity that is being questioned in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Generalization

 

  • In this scenario, the concern raised is whether the results of the study can be applied to other populations, particularly those with different characteristics or living in different environments. 
  • This pertains to external validity, which refers to the ability to generalize the findings of a study to broader groups or real-world settings. 
  • The study was conducted in a controlled environment with a specific group of patients, and the question is whether the results will apply to other, more diverse groups (e.g., elderly patients, those with comorbidities, or individuals living in the community). 
  • This is a classic example of questioning generalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Replicability: Replicability refers to the ability to repeat the study under the same conditions and obtain similar results. While replicability is essential for confirming the robustness of the findings, it is not the focus of this scenario, which is more concerned with whether the results can be applied outside the study context.

 

Option C. Objectivity: Objectivity refers to the neutrality in the study design and interpretation of results, ensuring that the study's findings are not influenced by bias or personal opinions. This concept is not directly related to the generalizability of the findings, which is the central concern in the scenario.

 

Option D. Causality: Causality concerns whether the study can establish a cause-and-effect relationship between the intervention and the outcome (e.g., whether the antihypertensive drug truly causes a reduction in blood pressure). This concept is more related to internal validity and does not directly address the issue of generalization to other populations or settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • External validity refers to the ability of a study's results to be generalized or applied to broader populations, settings, or real-world conditions.

questions.text: The maneuver depicted in the image below is being applied to assist in the delivery of the fetal head in a breech presentation. What is the name of this maneuver?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver

 

  • The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is used to assist in the delivery of the aftercoming head during breech delivery. This technique involves two key steps:
    1. The operator places one hand under the fetal body to support it while using two fingers of the same hand to flex the fetal head by applying pressure on the maxilla.
    2. The other hand is placed on the occiput to maintain head flexion.
  • This maneuver reduces the diameter of the presenting fetal head, facilitating its delivery through the maternal pelvis. 
  • The image clearly depicts this maneuver in action.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McRoberts maneuver: This maneuver is used to relieve shoulder dystocia by hyperflexing the maternal thighs to widen the pelvic outlet. It is not related to the delivery of the fetal head during breech delivery, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Rubin maneuver: The Rubin maneuver is also used for shoulder dystocia. It involves applying pressure on the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder to rotate it and reduce obstruction. This does not apply to the scenario depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Zavanelli maneuver: The Zavanelli maneuver involves pushing the fetal head back into the uterus to allow for cesarean delivery in cases of severe shoulder dystocia. It is not used for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is a key technique used in breech deliveries to assist with the delivery of the aftercoming head by maintaining flexion and reducing the presenting diameter. 
  • This maneuver is crucial in ensuring a safe delivery for both the mother and fetus.

questions.text: During the secondary survey of a trauma patient, an AMPLE history is taken to gather critical information. Which of the following is not a part of the AMPLE history?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Physical examination

 

  • Physical examination is not a component of the AMPLE history. 
  • The AMPLE history focuses on gathering vital background information to guide patient care during the secondary survey. 
  • AMPLE stands for:
    • A: Allergies
    • M: Medications
    • P: Past illnesses or pregnancy
    • L: Last meal
    • E: Events related to the injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergies: Part of the AMPLE history to identify potential reactions during treatment.

 

Option B. Medications: Important to understand current treatments or potential drug interactions.

 

Option C. Past illness or pregnancy: Relevant for identifying underlying conditions or specific considerations like pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The AMPLE history is a structured approach during the secondary survey of trauma patients, focusing on Allergies, Medications, Past illnesses or pregnancy, Last meal, and Events related to injury.

questions.text:
In a rural health setting, a male health worker is assigned several duties to support community health programs. Which of the following tasks is/are typically part of his responsibilities? 

 

  1. Sputum collection
  2. ORS distribution
  3. DOTS supervision
  4. Growth monitoring
  5. Environmental sanitation
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3 and 5

 

  • A male health worker typically performs the following tasks in community health programs:

 

1. Sputum collection: Male health workers are often responsible for collecting sputum samples for tuberculosis diagnosis.

 

2. ORS distribution: Male health workers are involved in distributing Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) for the treatment of dehydration, particularly in cases of diarrheal diseases.

 

3. DOTS supervision: Male health workers play a crucial role in the supervision of Directly Observed Treatment Short-course (DOTS), ensuring that patients adhere to tuberculosis treatment regimens.

 

5. Environmental sanitation: Ensuring proper environmental sanitation by promoting hygiene practices, waste disposal, and water cleanliness is a key responsibility.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Growth monitoring: Is usually a task for female health workers, especially those involved in maternal and child health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Male health workers are typically responsible for tasks such as sputum collection, ORS distribution, DOTS supervision, and environmental sanitation in community health programs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 16 weeks gestation undergoes routine prenatal screening. Her serum markers are analyzed to assess the risk of fetal chromosomal abnormalities. Among the markers evaluated, which one is not included in the standard quadruple screening panel?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconjugated estradiol

 

  • Unconjugated estradiol is not included in the standard quadruple (quad) screening panel used during prenatal care. 
  • The quadruple screen typically measures four specific serum markers to evaluate the risk of certain fetal conditions:
    1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): A protein produced by the fetal liver. Abnormal levels can indicate neural tube defects or abdominal wall defects.
    2. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG): A hormone produced by the placenta. Elevated levels are associated with Down syndrome.
    3. Estriol (unconjugated estriol): A hormone produced by both the fetus and the placenta. Low levels can be indicative of Down syndrome or Edwards syndrome.
    4. Inhibin-A: A hormone produced by the placenta. Elevated levels are associated with Down syndrome.
  • Unconjugated estradiol is a different estrogen hormone and is not part of the quad screen panel. Instead, estriol is the estrogen measured in this screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The quadruple marker screening in prenatal care includes alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), unconjugated estriol, and inhibin-A, and unconjugated estradiol is not part of this panel.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from a rural region presents with a hypopigmented skin lesion on his back. The lesion is non-tender, sensations are normal, and is not associated with any thickened nerves. He recalls experiencing prolonged episodes of fever in his childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

  • The patient’s presentation of normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions, absence of thickened nerves, and a history of prolonged fever (indicative of kala-azar/visceral leishmaniasis) strongly supports the diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL).
  • PKDL is a dermal sequela of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), caused by Leishmania donovani.
  • It typically occurs after recovery from the systemic illness, sometimes months or even years later. 
  • The absence of nerve thickening helps differentiate PKDL from leprosy. Hypopigmented macules are a classic dermatological feature in PKDL, particularly in endemic areas like Bihar, India, which has a high prevalence of leishmaniasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycosis fungoides: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with erythematous, scaly patches or plaques. It typically evolves slowly, and hypopigmented lesions are rare. The patient’s history of fever and residence in a leishmaniasis-endemic region makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Tuberculoid leprosy: Tuberculoid leprosy is a form of Hansen’s disease that presents with hypopigmented anesthetic skin lesions and thickened peripheral nerves. However, this patient lacks nerve thickening, a hallmark feature of leprosy. Additionally, the history of prolonged fever in childhood and geographical context favor PKDL.

 

Option D. Lepromatous leprosy: Lepromatous leprosy involves multiple nodular or diffuse lesions, often with symmetrical involvement. Sensory loss may occur late, and nerve thickening is common. The absence of multiple lesions or thickened nerves makes this diagnosis unlikely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In endemic regions, post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) should be suspected in patients presenting with hypopigmented skin lesions, particularly if there is a history of prior visceral leishmaniasis. 
  • The absence of nerve thickening is a key differentiator from leprosy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with two prior miscarriages presents with secondary infertility. A hysteroscopic examination reveals the below findings. What is the most appropriate next step in managing her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

  • The image shows intrauterine adhesions, which are often characterized by thin or filmy adhesions inside the uterine cavity. 
  • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the most appropriate management for this patient. 
  • The presence of intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome, is a common cause of secondary infertility, especially following procedures like dilatation and curettage (D&C) after miscarriages. 
  • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis involves the surgical removal of these adhesions using a hysteroscope, which helps restore the normal anatomy of the uterine cavity. 
  • This procedure can significantly improve fertility outcomes by eliminating the physical barriers that may prevent implantation or sustain a pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In-vitro fertilization: While IVF is a valuable assisted reproductive technology for various infertility issues, it does not address structural abnormalities within the uterine cavity such as intrauterine adhesions. Performing IVF without first resolving the adhesions may lead to suboptimal outcomes.

 

Option B. Tubal recanalization: This procedure is indicated for addressing tubal obstructions or blockages that impede the passage of sperm or the embryo. However, in this case, the primary issue is intrauterine adhesions rather than tubal pathology, making tubal recanalization inappropriate.

 

Option D. Hysteroscopic septal resection: This procedure is performed to correct a septate uterus, a congenital anomaly characterized by a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity. The patient's hysteroscopic findings indicate intrauterine adhesions rather than a septate uterine structure, making septal resection unsuitable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the definitive treatment for intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) identified on hysteroscopy, effectively addressing secondary infertility caused by uterine scar tissue.

questions.text:
In the context of cancer metastasis, which of the following statements regarding the role of adhesion molecules is accurate?

 

Statement A: E-cadherin downregulation is often observed in tumor cells, allowing them to detach from primary tumors and invade surrounding tissues.


Statement B: Integrins play a crucial role in mediating the attachment of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, facilitating metastatic spread.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both Statement A and Statement B are correct.

 

Statement A: E-cadherin is a cell adhesion molecule that plays a critical role in maintaining epithelial cell integrity by mediating cell-to-cell adhesion. Its downregulation is frequently observed in tumor cells, enabling them to lose their cohesive property, detach from the primary tumor, and invade surrounding tissues. This process is a hallmark of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), a key step in cancer metastasis.

 

Statement B: Integrins are transmembrane proteins that mediate cell-extracellular matrix (ECM) interactions and are crucial in cancer metastasis. In metastatic spread, integrins play a vital role in the adhesion of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, facilitating extravasation and colonization. This interaction is essential for the metastatic cascade, allowing tumor cells to anchor themselves at distant sites and establish secondary tumors.

 

Both statements accurately describe distinct mechanisms by which adhesion molecules contribute to cancer metastasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cancer metastasis, E-cadherin downregulation facilitates tumor cell detachment from the primary tumor, while integrins mediate the adhesion of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, enabling metastatic spread.
  • Both mechanisms are critical in the metastatic cascade.

questions.text: A 9-month-old male infant develops progressive renal and hepatic failure. Despite intensive medical therapy, he passes away. Autopsy reveals kidneys with the gross appearance shown in the image below. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal recessive

 

  • The described condition is autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), a severe form of cystic kidney disease that presents in infancy. 
  • The disease is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, which encodes fibrocystin, a protein involved in renal and biliary duct development. 
  • The linear arrangement of cysts within the kidneys is characteristic of ARPKD, as the cysts originate from dilated collecting ducts. 
  • ARPKD often leads to progressive renal failure and hepatic fibrosis, contributing to mortality in affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondrial inheritance: Mitochondrial inheritance is associated with conditions caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA, typically affecting energy-dependent organs like the brain and muscles. It is not related to polycystic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) presents later in life, typically in adulthood, with cysts randomly distributed throughout the kidneys. It does not exhibit the smooth external surface or the linear cyst pattern seen in ARPKD.

 

Option D. Multifactorial inheritance: Multifactorial inheritance involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors. While multifactorial inheritance can underlie some conditions, it is not the cause of ARPKD, which follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) presents in infancy with smooth external kidney surfaces and linear cysts on cut section. 
  • It is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, leading to renal and hepatic failure.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for early-onset puberty. On examination, she has café-au-lait spots with irregular, "coast of Maine" borders. Imaging reveals polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and hormonal tests confirm hyperfunction of multiple endocrine glands. What is the underlying genetic mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GNAS gene mutation

 

  • McCune Albright syndrome is caused by a somatic mutation in the GNAS gene, which leads to constitutive activation of G-protein signaling. 
  • Clinical features include café-au-lait spots, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and endocrine hyperfunction, such as precocious puberty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation in the FBN1 gene: Associated with Marfan syndrome, characterized by connective tissue abnormalities, tall stature, and cardiovascular complications.

 

Option B. Mutation in the TBCE gene: Associated with Kenny-Caffey syndrome, which includes hypocalcemia, delayed closure of fontanelles, and skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Stat3 mutation: Associated with Hyper-IgE syndrome, leading to recurrent infections, eczema, and elevated IgE levels.

 

Educational Objective :

 

McCune Albright syndrome results from a GNAS gene mutation, causing hyperfunction of endocrine glands, café-au-lait spots, and fibrous dysplasia.

questions.text: Based on the information in the graph, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elimination half-life of the drug is approximately 2 hours

 

  • The elimination half-life (t1/2) of a drug refers to the time required for its plasma concentration to decrease by 50%. Based on the graph:
    • At 3 hours, the plasma concentration is 100 mg/dl.
    • By 5 hours, the concentration decreases to 50 mg/dl.
  • This 50% reduction in concentration over the 2-hour period indicates that the elimination half-life of the drug is approximately 2 hours. Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax of the drug is 3 hours: Incorrect. Tmax is the time at which the drug reaches its maximum concentration (Cmax). Based on the graph, Cmax is reached at 2 hours, not 3 hours. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect.

 

Option B. Cmax of the drug in this graph is 100 mg/dl: Incorrect. Cmax is the maximum plasma concentration the drug reaches after administration. In this graph, the maximum concentration (Cmax) is shown as 120 mg/dl, not 100 mg/dl. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect.

 

Option D. The graph can be used to calculate ED50: Incorrect. ED50 refers to the dose of a drug required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the population and is typically derived from a quantal dose-response curve (DRC), not a plasma concentration vs. time graph. The graph in question provides pharmacokinetic information, not pharmacodynamic information, so it cannot be used to calculate ED50. Therefore, option (D) is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The elimination half-life of a drug can be estimated by observing the time it takes for its plasma concentration to decrease by 50%.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to progressive visual impairment. On examination, the child is obese, has intellectual disability, and is noted to have polydactyly. The parents also report anosmia and poor academic performance. Retinitis pigmentosa is confirmed on fundoscopy. A cardiac murmur is noted, and renal function tests reveal mild impairment. Based on the clinical features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laurence Moon Biedl syndrome

 

  • Laurence Moon Biedl syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a combination of obesity, intellectual disability, retinal dystrophy (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa), renal anomalies, polydactyly, and hypogonadism. 
  • These features match the clinical presentation described in the scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down syndrome: Characterized by trisomy 21, features include intellectual disability, characteristic facial dysmorphism, and congenital heart disease, but retinitis pigmentosa and polydactyly are not typical.

 

Option C. Marfan syndrome: A connective tissue disorder with tall stature, arachnodactyly, lens dislocation, and cardiovascular complications, which do not fit this presentation.

 

Option D. Ellis van Creveld syndrome: Features include polydactyly and congenital heart disease, but it is also associated with chondrodystrophy and other features not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Laurence Moon Biedl syndrome is characterized by a combination of retinal dystrophy, obesity, polydactyly, intellectual disability, and renal anomalies.

questions.text: A worker in a radiation industry is being scheduled for periodic post-placement medical examinations. How often should these examinations be performed according to occupational health guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Every 2 months

 

  • For workers in high-risk industries, such as the radiation industry, periodic medical examinations should be conducted every 2 months to closely monitor their physical health due to the increased risk of radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old postmenopausal woman arrives at the gynecology clinic reporting a persistent, foul-smelling vaginal discharge that has been present for several weeks. She also notices blood-tinged mucus intermittently. On pelvic examination, there is an ulcerative, necrotic lesion on the cervix extending into the surrounding parametrium. There are no palpable lymph nodes or signs of distant metastasis. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Concurrent chemoradiation

 

  • Concurrent chemoradiation is the most appropriate management for this patient, who presents with a necrotizing cervical lesion involving the lateral parametrium, indicative of locally advanced cervical cancer (Stage IIB or higher according to FIGO staging). 
  • This combination therapy, typically involving cisplatin-based chemotherapy with external beam radiation followed by brachytherapy, is the standard of care for locally advanced cervical cancer. 
  • It enhances local control of the tumor and improves overall survival rates compared to single-modality treatments. 
  • The involvement of the parametrium signifies that the disease has extended beyond the cervix but without distant metastasis, making chemoradiation the optimal choice to address both the primary tumor and any potential microscopic spread within the pelvic region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: While chemotherapy is an essential component of treatment for cervical cancer, using it alone is insufficient for locally advanced cases with parametral involvement. Chemotherapy alone does not provide the necessary local control that radiation therapy offers, making it inadequate as a sole treatment modality in this scenario.

 

Option B. Surgery: Radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection is typically reserved for early-stage cervical cancer (Stage IA to IIA without parametral involvement). In cases where there is involvement of the parametrium, as seen in this patient, surgery alone is not recommended due to the high risk of residual disease and lower survival rates compared to chemoradiation.

 

Option D. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is an important component of definitive treatment for cervical cancer, particularly after external beam radiation and chemotherapy. However, using brachytherapy as a standalone treatment without concurrent chemotherapy and external beam radiation is inadequate for managing advanced local disease with parametral involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Concurrent chemoradiation is the standard treatment for locally advanced cervical cancer with parametral involvement, as it provides superior local control and improved survival compared to single-modality treatments such as surgery, chemotherapy, or brachytherapy alone.

questions.text:
Based on its intrinsic resistance profile, which of the following antibiotics is Proteus mirabilis resistant to?

 

1. Nitrofurantoin
2. Cephalosporins
3. Tetracycline
4. Ampicillin
5. Ampicillin-sulbactam
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

 

  • Proteus mirabilis is intrinsically resistant to certain antibiotics due to its genetic and biological mechanisms. Specifically, Proteus mirabilis shows intrinsic resistance to the following:
    • Nitrofurantoin (1): This antibiotic is poorly penetrated by Proteus mirabilis, and the bacterium is unable to accumulate it to effective concentrations. Therefore, it is intrinsically resistant to nitrofurantoin.
    • Tetracycline (3): Proteus mirabilis has efflux pumps that expel tetracycline from the cell and also has modifications in its ribosomal target, making it intrinsically resistant to tetracycline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 2 and 5: Proteus mirabilis is not intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins or ampicillin-sulbactam. In fact, it is usually susceptible to cephalosporins, especially first-generation cephalosporins. Ampicillin-sulbactam is also effective because sulbactam inhibits beta-lactamase production, which can otherwise degrade ampicillin.

 

Option 4: Proteus mirabilis is not intrinsically resistant to ampicillin. Proteus mirabilis is typically susceptible to ampicillin unless resistance has been acquired through beta-lactamase production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Proteus mirabilis is intrinsically resistant to nitrofurantoin and tetracycline due to mechanisms such as poor cellular penetration (for nitrofurantoin) and efflux pumps (for tetracycline). Understanding intrinsic resistance patterns is critical when selecting appropriate antibiotics for treatment.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old patient presents with cough, wheezing, and eosinophilia. After further evaluation, it is found that the patient has been infected with a parasitic worm. Which of the following larvae travel through the lungs during their life cycle?

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis
  2. Ascaris lumbricoides
  3. Necator americanus
  4. Trichuris trichiura
  5. Wuchereria bancrofti microfilaria
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3 and 5

 

  • The larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis, Ascaris lumbricoides, Necator americanus, and the microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti all travel through the lungs during their life cycle. Here's how each of these parasites behaves:

 

1. Strongyloides stercoralis: The larvae hatch in the intestines, penetrate the intestinal wall, and travel through the bloodstream to the lungs. From the lungs, they migrate up the trachea, are swallowed, and mature in the intestines.

 

2. Ascaris lumbricoides: The larvae of Ascaris hatch in the intestines, travel through the bloodstream to the lungs, where they mature, and then ascend up the trachea, are swallowed again, and develop into adult worms in the intestines.

 

3. Necator americanus (hookworm): The larvae penetrate the skin, enter the bloodstream, and then travel to the lungs. In the lungs, they mature, ascend the respiratory tract, are swallowed, and reach the intestines.

 

5. Wuchereria bancrofti microfilaria: These microfilariae are released into the bloodstream, and while they do not directly infect the lungs, they are filtered out of the bloodstream by the lungs, causing an allergic reaction known as Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE), which can manifest with cough, wheezing, and eosinophilia.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) does not have a larval stage that travels through the lungs. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis, Ascaris lumbricoides, Necator americanus, and Wuchereria bancrofti microfilariae all pass through the lungs during their life cycle, which is a key aspect of their developmental stages. 
  • Trichuris trichiura, however, does not follow this pattern.

questions.text:
Which of the following bacteria are non-sporing anaerobes. Select the correct combination of bacteria that fall into this category.

 

1. Peptostreptococcus

2. Propionibacterium

3. Clostridium

4. Anthrax

5. Bacteroides
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5

 

  • Non-sporing anaerobic bacteria are those that do not form spores and typically grow in environments without oxygen. 
  • The correct bacteria in the options that are non-sporing anaerobes are:

 

1. Peptostreptococcus: A non-sporing anaerobic gram-positive cocci that is part of the normal flora but can cause infections in various body sites.

 

2. Propionibacterium: A non-sporing, gram-positive anaerobic bacterium commonly found in human skin and is also associated with acne and other infections.

 

5. Bacteroides: A genus of non-sporing anaerobic gram-negative rods that are abundant in the human gut microbiota and can cause infections if they translocate from the intestine to other parts of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

3. and 4. Clostridium (option 3) is sporing and therefore not correct for this group of non-sporing anaerobes. Anthrax (option 4), caused by Bacillus anthracis, is also a spore-forming bacterium, not non-sporing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-sporing anaerobic bacteria include genera like Peptostreptococcus, Propionibacterium, and Bacteroides, which do not produce spores and are often found in human body sites. 
  • Clostridium and Anthrax, on the other hand, are spore-forming and are not included in the non-sporing category.

questions.text: A factory manager is concerned about maintaining proper air quality in the production area where workers are exposed to dust and fumes. To ensure a healthy working environment, the manager needs to determine the minimum number of air changes per hour that should be implemented in the workroom. What is the recommended number of air changes per hour for optimal ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-6

 

  • In workrooms where workers are exposed to airborne contaminants, it is crucial to maintain a high level of ventilation. 
  • The recommended minimum number of air changes per hour for optimal air quality in such environments is 4-6. 
  • This ensures adequate removal of pollutants and replenishment of oxygen, reducing the risk of respiratory issues and ensuring a safe working environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For workrooms with exposure to contaminants, the minimum recommended number of air changes per hour is 4-6 to maintain air quality and protect worker health.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with poorly controlled gestational diabetes delivers a full-term infant. During the newborn assessment, the pediatrician notes a congenital anomaly. What is the most common congenital abnormality seen in infants of diabetic mothers?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital heart disease

 

  • Congenital heart disease is the most common congenital abnormality in infants of diabetic mothers (IDM). 
  • Poor glycemic control during early pregnancy increases the risk of fetal malformations, especially cardiac anomalies, such as ventricular septal defects and transposition of the great arteries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular septal defect: Although this is a common specific cardiac anomaly in IDM, it is part of the broader category of congenital heart disease.

 

Option B. Neural tube defect: Neural tube defects can occur in IDM but are less common compared to congenital heart defects.

 

Option D. Cleft palate: Cleft palate is not commonly associated with maternal diabetes and is less frequent than congenital heart disease in IDM.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Congenital heart disease is the most common congenital anomaly in infants of diabetic mothers, emphasizing the importance of strict glycemic control during pregnancy.

Rightward shift due to decreased PaCO₂
