New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM)-mediated carbapenem resistance has been identified in which of the following bacterial species? 

 

  1. Citrobacter freundii
  2. Escherichia coli
  3. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  4. Klebsiella pneumoniae
  5. Acinetobacter baumannii
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM) is an enzyme that mediates resistance to carbapenems, a class of antibiotics often used as a last-line treatment for multidrug-resistant (MDR) infections. 
  • NDM-producing organisms are capable of hydrolyzing the beta-lactam ring in carbapenems, rendering these antibiotics ineffective.
  • The NDM-producing bacteria that are known to exhibit carbapenem resistance include:
    • Citrobacter freundii: This is one of the Enterobacteriaceae species that has been shown to produce NDM, leading to resistance to carbapenems.
    • Escherichia coli: This common intestinal bacterium is known to acquire NDM-mediated resistance, contributing to challenges in treating urinary tract and bloodstream infections.
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: A common pathogen in hospital-associated infections, P. aeruginosa can produce NDM, leading to multidrug resistance, including to carbapenems.
    • Klebsiella pneumoniae: Another important member of the Enterobacteriaceae family, K. pneumoniae frequently produces NDM, which can make it resistant to several classes of antibiotics, including carbapenems.
    • Acinetobacter baumannii: A highly antibiotic-resistant pathogen, A. baumannii has also been found to produce NDM, contributing to its resistance to carbapenems and other beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Thus, all of the above organisms are known to produce New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM) and exhibit carbapenem resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM) is a key mechanism of carbapenem resistance and can be produced by a range of organisms, including Citrobacter freundii, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Acinetobacter baumannii. 
  • Understanding the broad spectrum of NDM-producing organisms is crucial for effective antibiotic stewardship and treatment of multidrug-resistant infections.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a painless thyroid mass that has progressively enlarged over several months. A biopsy of the thyroid reveals the histological findings shown in the image below. Further analysis confirms the presence of amyloid deposits. What type of amyloid protein is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ACal

 

  • The slide shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are histological findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC). 
  • MTC arises from parafollicular C cells, which produce calcitonin. 
  • The major fibril protein that gets deposited in this condition is ACal, derived from calcitonin. 
  • These amyloid deposits in the stroma are a hallmark of MTC and help differentiate it from other thyroid cancers.
  • MTC can occur sporadically or as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2 syndromes. 
  • The presence of amyloid deposits supports the diagnosis of MTC and highlights the role of calcitonin in its pathophysiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aβ: Aβ amyloid deposits are associated with Alzheimer disease, where amyloid-beta plaques accumulate in the brain. This is unrelated to thyroid pathology or medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option B. Aβ2: Aβ2 amyloid deposits are not a recognized subtype of amyloid in clinical practice. This option does not pertain to amyloid deposits in thyroid conditions.

 

Option C. AA: AA amyloid is associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and chronic infections. It is derived from serum amyloid A protein and is not related to thyroid carcinoma or calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by ACal amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin, produced by parafollicular C cells. 
  • Amyloid-rich stroma and nests of polygonal cells are histological hallmarks of the disease.

questions.text:
For the routine culture of anaerobic bacteria, which of the following specimens are considered appropriate for collection?

 

1. Tissue specimen

2. Blood

3. Vaginal swab

4. Bone marrow

5. Sputum
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

  • When performing anaerobic bacterial culture, certain specimens are considered appropriate because they are more likely to yield anaerobic organisms. The correct specimens for anaerobic culture include:

 

1. Tissue specimen: Tissue specimens (such as biopsies or excised tissue) are ideal for anaerobic culture as they provide a direct source of the infection and are less likely to be contaminated by ambient air.

 

2. Blood: Blood is another appropriate specimen for anaerobic culture, especially when the infection is suspected to be systemic (bacteremia) and caused by anaerobes.

 

4. Bone marrow: Bone marrow is an excellent specimen for anaerobic culture, particularly in cases of systemic infections or when bone or joint infections are suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Vaginal swab is not typically recommended for anaerobic culture because vaginal flora often includes a large number of aerobic bacteria. In addition, routine anaerobic cultures are not performed on vaginal swabs unless specific anaerobic infections (e.g., bacterial vaginosis) are suspected.

 

5. Sputum is generally not suitable for anaerobic culture because it is often contaminated with upper respiratory tract flora, which may include aerobic organisms. Voided sputum is less likely to contain anaerobic bacteria in a reliable, cultured form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For routine anaerobic cultures, the appropriate specimens include tissue specimens, blood, and bone marrow, while specimens like vaginal swabs, sputum, and voided urine are generally not suitable for anaerobic culture due to contamination by aerobic organisms or their inability to support anaerobic bacterial growth.

choices.text: Presence of calcification within the tumor

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is diagnosed with retinoblastoma, and an enucleation is performed. The pathology report shows tumor involvement. Which of the following findings is most strongly associated with increased mortality in the case of an enucleated eye with retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Involvement of the Optic nerve

 

  • In retinoblastoma, the involvement of the optic nerve is a critical factor that increases the risk of metastasis and poor prognosis. 
  • When the tumor invades the optic nerve, it signifies that the cancer may have spread beyond the eye, which significantly increases the chances of mortality. 
  • Optic nerve involvement indicates a higher risk of extraocular extension, which is a serious concern as it may lead to distant metastases (e.g., to the brain or spinal cord), thereby worsening the outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presence of calcification within the tumor: While calcification is a common feature of retinoblastoma, it is not an indicator of poor prognosis by itself. Calcifications can occur in well-differentiated tumors and are not associated with an increased risk of mortality.

 

Option C. Necrosis within the tumor: Necrosis is a common feature in retinoblastomas, particularly in larger tumors, but it does not necessarily correlate with a poor prognosis. Tumor necrosis may be seen in both low and high-risk retinoblastoma cases.

 

Option D. Exophytic retinoblastoma: Exophytic growth refers to the tumor growing outward from the retina into the vitreous cavity. Although exophytic retinoblastoma can lead to severe visual impairment, it is not a direct indicator of mortality. Tumor extension into the optic nerve (infiltration) is a much more significant concern for prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In retinoblastoma, involvement of the optic nerve is a strong prognostic factor that significantly increases the risk of metastasis and mortality.

questions.text: To evaluate the hemodynamic changes in the portal circulation, particularly to identify a reversal of blood flow away from the liver, which imaging technique is most appropriate and sensitive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colour Doppler

 

  • Colour Doppler ultrasound is the most appropriate and sensitive modality for detecting changes in portal venous flow, especially the shift from hepatopetal (toward the liver) to hepatofugal (away from the liver) flow. 
  • It visualizes blood flow direction and velocity by overlaying color information on standard ultrasound images, allowing accurate assessment of hemodynamic alterations in conditions like portal hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. M-Mode Ultrasound: Primarily used for evaluating motion, such as cardiac structures, and does not provide information on blood flow direction or velocity in the portal system.

 

Option B. A-Mode Ultrasound: Offers a one-dimensional representation of tissue structures based on amplitude but cannot assess blood flow dynamics or direction.

 

Option D. B-Mode Ultrasound: Provides detailed anatomical images but lacks the capability to evaluate blood flow direction and velocity without Doppler functionality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour Doppler ultrasound is the most appropriate and sensitive diagnostic tool for detecting changes in portal venous flow, specifically the reversal from hepatopetal to hepatofugal flow in portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, increased sweating, weight loss, and gingival bleeding. On examination, splenomegaly is noted. Laboratory findings are as given below. Molecular testing confirms the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22]). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Imatinib therapy

 

  • The patient’s presentation, laboratory findings (leukocytosis with left shift and thrombocytosis), and molecular confirmation of the Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22]) are diagnostic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). 
  • Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) targeting the BCR-ABL fusion protein, is the first-line treatment for chronic-phase CML. 
  • It is highly effective in achieving cytogenetic and molecular remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vincristine, prednisone, and asparaginase therapy: Incorrect, this regimen is used for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not CML.

 

Option B. Cytarabine and daunorubicin therapy: Incorrect, this combination is used for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), not CML.

 

Option C. Allogeneic stem cell transplantation: Incorrect, Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is reserved for advanced or TKI-resistant cases of CML, not as an initial therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Imatinib and other tyrosine kinase inhibitors are the cornerstone of chronic-phase CML treatment, offering excellent outcomes and prolonged survival. 
  • Early identification and initiation of therapy are essential for optimal management.

choices.text: Decreased RPF, decreased GFR, unchanged FF
Decreased RPF, increased GFR, increased FF
Increased RPF, decreased GFR, decreased FF
Increased RPF, increased GFR, unchanged FF

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with elevated blood pressure and is found to have increased renal vascular resistance. Constriction of the afferent arteriole would most likely result in which of the following changes to renal plasma flow (RPF), glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and filtration fraction (FF)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased RPF, decreased GFR, unchanged FF

 

  • Constriction of the afferent arteriole reduces blood flow into the glomerulus, leading to the following effects:
    • Renal Plasma Flow (RPF): Decreases due to increased resistance in the afferent arteriole, limiting blood entry into the glomerulus.
    • Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR): Decreases as a result of reduced glomerular hydrostatic pressure from diminished blood flow.
    • Filtration Fraction (FF): Defined as GFR divided by RPF. Both GFR and RPF decrease proportionally, resulting in an unchanged FF.
  • Therefore, afferent arteriole constriction leads to decreased RPF and GFR, with no significant change in FF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Constriction of the afferent arteriole decreases both renal plasma flow and glomerular filtration rate, resulting in an unchanged filtration fraction.

questions.text: The study of entomology in cadavers helps in determining which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Time since death

 

  • Forensic entomology involves the study of insects found on a cadaver to help estimate the time since death (postmortem interval or PMI). 
  • Insects, particularly blowflies, are the first to colonize a body after death, and the developmental stages of these insects (eggs, larvae, pupae) can be used to estimate how long the body has been deceased. 
  • The time since death can be approximated by analyzing the species present and their life cycle stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mode of death: Incorrect: The mode of death (e.g., drowning, shooting) refers to how death occurred, which forensic entomology does not directly determine.

 

Option C. Manner of death: Incorrect: Manner of death (e.g., accidental, natural, homicide) is a broader concept that includes investigating the circumstances, not just insect evidence.

 

Option D. Identify the disease: Incorrect: Forensic entomology is not used to identify diseases. It is more focused on estimating the time of death based on insect activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Forensic entomology is used to estimate the time since death by studying the development of insect species on the body.

choices.text: Between the medial malleolus and lateral border of the tendo calcaneus in inversion
Between the medial malleolus and medial border of the tendo calcaneus in inversion
Between the medial malleolus and medial border of the tendo calcaneus in eversion
Between the medial malleolus and lateral border of the tendo calcaneus in eversion

questions.text: A 25-year-old man sustains injuries to both upper and lower limbs after an accident. While assessing the patient’s vital signs, the clinician decides to check the pulse of the posterior tibial artery at the ankle. At which of the following locations can the posterior tibial artery be palpated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between the medial malleolus and medial border of the tendo calcaneus in inversion

 

  • The posterior tibial artery is a major artery of the leg and its pulse can be palpated at the ankle. 
  • It is located between the medial malleolus and the medial border of the tendo calcaneus. 
  • To optimize palpation, the foot is slightly inverted to relax the overlying structures and make the artery more accessible. 
  • This location is crucial for assessing blood flow to the distal limb.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Between the medial malleolus and lateral border of the tendo calcaneus in inversion: This is anatomically incorrect as the posterior tibial artery lies medially, not laterally, relative to the tendo calcaneus.

 

Option C. Between the medial malleolus and medial border of the tendo calcaneus in eversion: While the artery is correctly described as being medial, eversion tenses the structures around the artery, making the pulse more difficult to palpate.

 

Option D. Between the medial malleolus and lateral border of the tendo calcaneus in eversion: This is incorrect for two reasons: the posterior tibial artery is not lateral, and eversion would further obscure the artery's palpation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The posterior tibial artery can be palpated between the medial malleolus and the medial border of the tendo calcaneus with the foot in slight inversion. 
  • This is an important site for assessing distal blood flow.

choices.text: Between the external oblique and transversus abdominis
Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis
Between the external and internal oblique
Between the transversus abdominis and fascia transversalis

questions.text: At which of the following anatomical locations does neurovascular bundle run?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

 

  • The neurovascular bundle in the abdominal wall, which includes the intercostal nerves, subcostal nerve, and associated vessels, runs in the plane between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. 
  • This location is consistent throughout most of the abdominal wall and is important for safe surgical approaches and procedures like regional anesthesia (e.g., transversus abdominis plane block). 
  • This arrangement provides protection to the neurovascular structures by placing them between muscle layers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Between the external oblique and transversus abdominis: This is incorrect as the neurovascular bundle is situated deeper, specifically between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Option C. Between the external and internal oblique: The neurovascular bundle does not run at this level. This plane is superficial to the actual location of the neurovascular structures.

 

Option D. Between the transversus abdominis and fascia transversalis: This is incorrect, as this location is even deeper than the neurovascular bundle’s typical position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neurovascular bundle in the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with acute dehydration secondary to gastroenteritis. The patient is hemodynamically stable but requires intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation. The attending physician orders an IV cannula for fluid administration, and the nurse is considering the appropriate gauge of the cannula to be used based on the required flow rate for adequate resuscitation. Which of the following IV cannula sizes would be most appropriate for this patient’s fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18G

 

  • An 18G IV cannula is most appropriate in this clinical scenario for the following reasons:
    • Flow Rate: The 18G cannula can deliver 103 ml/min, which is sufficient for rapid fluid resuscitation, especially in a patient with acute dehydration. It strikes a balance between providing adequate flow and minimizing the risk of complications associated with larger cannulas.
    • Clinical Context: For most adult patients undergoing moderate fluid resuscitation (e.g., in cases of gastroenteritis with dehydration), an 18G cannula is a commonly used size. It provides an adequate flow rate without the need for excessive vascular access, which can be associated with complications (e.g., hematoma, phlebitis) when larger cannulas like 14G are used unless indicated for severe hemorrhage or trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 14G: A 14G cannula is capable of delivering a very high flow rate (270 ml/min) and is typically used in emergency situations where rapid blood transfusion or high-flow resuscitation is necessary (e.g., trauma or severe shock). While it can be used in this case, it is usually reserved for critical conditions and is not necessary for the moderate fluid resuscitation of a stable patient with dehydration.

 

Option C. 22G: A 22G cannula provides a slower flow rate (42 ml/min) and is typically used for less urgent or smaller-volume fluid administration. While it could be used for maintenance fluids in a stable patient, it would not be ideal for fluid resuscitation in this case where a more rapid infusion rate is required.

 

Option D. 24G: A 24G cannula is even smaller (20 ml/min flow rate) and is generally used for pediatric patients or in cases where venous access is difficult. It is not suitable for rapid fluid resuscitation in adults, as its flow rate is insufficient for the immediate needs of this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For most adult patients requiring moderate fluid resuscitation, an 18G IV cannula is ideal due to its balanced flow rate of 103 ml/min, which allows for effective fluid administration without the complications of larger or smaller gauge cannulas. Larger gauges (e.g., 14G) are reserved for critical situations requiring high-flow resuscitation. Smaller gauges (e.g., 22G, 24G) are suitable for maintenance fluids but are not optimal for rapid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old non-smoker presents with a 3-month history of persistent dry cough, low-grade fever, and fatigue. She reports mild weight loss and no significant occupational exposure. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral patchy opacities, and CT scan shown below. A lung biopsy shows intra-alveolar fibroblastic plugs without significant interstitial fibrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)

 

  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP), previously called bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), is an interstitial lung disease characterized by non-infectious inflammation of the small airways and alveoli. Key features include:
    • Persistent cough and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue).
    • Imaging findings of bilateral patchy consolidations with peripheral distribution on CT.
    • Histological finding of intra-alveolar plugs of fibroblasts and inflammatory cells, with preservation of the lung architecture and no significant interstitial fibrosis.
      Treatment involves corticosteroids, which often lead to marked improvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF): Incorrect, IPF typically presents with progressive dyspnea and dry cough, along with imaging findings of honeycombing and subpleural fibrosis. Histology shows interstitial fibrosis rather than intra-alveolar plugs.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect, Sarcoidosis presents with non-caseating granulomas on biopsy and is often associated with hilar lymphadenopathy, which is absent in this case.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: Incorrect, Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results from inhalation of organic antigens and is associated with diffuse ground-glass opacities or centrilobular nodules on CT. This patient lacks the typical exposure history.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia should be suspected in patients with persistent cough, systemic symptoms, and patchy consolidations on imaging. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with histology showing intra-alveolar fibroblastic plugs, and treatment with corticosteroids is usually effective.

choices.text: Upper lip bite test: Ability to protrude mandible

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese male is scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, hypertension, and a BMI of 35. Preoperative airway assessment is performed to determine if the patient has a difficult airway, as this could complicate the intubation process during the surgery. Based on the clinical tests, which of the following findings would classify this patient as having a "difficult airway"?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mallampati score III

 

  • A Mallampati score of III (the third classification) is an indicator of a difficult airway, as it means that only the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible during mouth opening, with limited visualization of the oropharynx. 
  • This could suggest difficulty with intubation, particularly when using conventional laryngoscopy.

 

Key Tests for Difficult Airway:

 

  1. Mallampati Score: A higher Mallampati score (III or IV) is associated with a difficult airway. A score of III (only the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible) and IV (only the hard palate is visible) suggest a potentially difficult airway.
  2. Thyromental Distance: If the thyromental distance is less than 6 cm, it suggests a short neck or limited mobility, making it difficult to visualize the airway during intubation. In this case, a thyromental distance of 7 cm would not be considered a risk factor for a difficult airway.
  3. Sterno-mental Distance: A sternomental distance of <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension is a predictor of a difficult airway because it indicates limited mobility of the neck or short neck length. In this patient, the sterno-mental distance is 13 cm, which is within normal range and does not suggest difficulty.
  4. Upper Lip Bite Test: If a patient cannot protrude their mandible or bite the upper lip (inability to bite the upper lip with the lower teeth), it is indicative of a potentially difficult airway. However, in this scenario, the patient has the ability to protrude the mandible, suggesting that the upper lip bite test is negative for difficulty.
  5. Increased Neck Circumference: A neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women is associated with difficult intubation due to restricted access or limited neck extension. This test was not specifically mentioned in the scenario but is a relevant factor for airway difficulty in obese patients.
  6. Cormack and Lehane Grade: The Cormack and Lehane classification grades the laryngeal view during laryngoscopy. A Grade III or IV view indicates difficulty in intubating due to poor visualization of the vocal cords. However, this test is performed during the intubation process and cannot be assessed preoperatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyromental distance 7 cm: This is within normal range and does not indicate a difficult airway. The threshold for difficulty is generally considered to be less than 6 cm.

 

Option C. Sterno-mental distance 13 cm: This is also within normal range. A sterno-mental distance of less than 12.5 cm would be more concerning for difficulty.

 

Option D. Upper lip bite test: Ability to protrude mandible: If the patient can protrude the mandible and bite the upper lip, the upper lip bite test is negative for airway difficulty. Therefore, this does not classify as a difficult airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Mallampati score of III (with only the soft palate and base of the uvula visible) is a strong predictor of a difficult airway, and it should raise concerns during preoperative airway assessment. 
  • Other factors, such as a thyromental distance <6 cm, sternomental distance <12.5 cm, or neck circumference >17 inches in men could also contribute to airway difficulty.

choices.text: Complement activation due to immune complexes

questions.text: A 47-year-old man undergoes a kidney transplant. Within minutes of reperfusion, the transplanted kidney becomes pale, mottled, and fails to produce urine. Further investigation reveals rapid vascular thrombosis in the graft. This type of rejection is most likely caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preformed antibodies

 

  • The above condition is hyperacute rejection. Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed antibodies in the recipient's blood recognize antigens on the donor organ. 
  • These antibodies are most commonly directed against ABO blood group antigens or HLA antigens. 
  • Upon recognition, the antibodies bind to endothelial cells in the graft, activating the complement cascade. This leads to endothelial damage, platelet aggregation, and rapid vascular thrombosis, resulting in ischemia and graft failure.
  • Hyperacute rejection develops within minutes to hours of transplantation and is irreversible, necessitating immediate removal of the graft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Natural killer (NK) cells: Natural killer cells are involved in innate immunity and contribute to immune responses against virally infected or cancerous cells. They do not mediate the rapid vascular thrombosis and graft failure characteristic of hyperacute rejection.

 

Option B. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes: Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes are responsible for acute cellular rejection, which occurs days to weeks after transplantation. Acute rejection involves T-cell-mediated destruction of graft tissue, not the immediate graft failure seen in hyperacute rejection.

 

Option D. Complement activation due to immune complexes: While complement activation is part of the hyperacute rejection mechanism, it is triggered by preformed antibodies binding to donor antigens, not by immune complexes formed after transplantation. Immune complexes are more relevant to other immunopathologies, such as type III hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperacute rejection occurs due to preformed antibodies in the recipient that bind to donor antigens, activating the complement cascade and leading to rapid vascular thrombosis and graft failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of hyperlipidemia is prescribed statins for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease. Which of the following drug interactions would most likely increase the risk of rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury (AKI) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythromycin

 

  • Statins, such as simvastatin, are metabolized through the CYP3A4 enzyme pathway. 
  • Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor and can significantly increase the plasma levels of simvastatin. 
  • This leads to an increased risk of rhabdomyolysis, which can cause acute kidney injury (AKI) due to muscle breakdown products (e.g., myoglobin) accumulating in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antacids containing aluminium: While antacids may reduce the absorption of certain drugs, they do not significantly interfere with the CYP3A4 metabolism of simvastatin or increase the risk of rhabdomyolysis.

 

Option C. Metformin: Metformin does not interact with CYP3A4 and is not known to significantly increase the risk of rhabdomyolysis when taken with statins. However, metformin can cause lactic acidosis in rare cases, but this is unrelated to simvastatin therapy.

 

Option D. Rifampin: Although rifampin is a potent CYP3A4 inducer, it would likely reduce the efficacy of simvastatin by increasing its metabolism, potentially lowering statin levels and reducing the risk of rhabdomyolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythromycin is a CYP3A4 inhibitor and can significantly increase simvastatin levels, leading to a higher risk of rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: McMurray’s Osteotomy is based on the principal of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bio-Mechanical

 

  • Biomechanics is the study of how biological systems (like the human body) respond to mechanical forces. In orthopedic surgery, biomechanical principles combine the mechanical alignment of bones and joints with an understanding of the biological responses to those mechanical changes. This is essential when performing surgeries like osteotomies, which aim to correct deformities while also considering how the body will heal and respond.
  • McMurray's Osteotomy combines both the biological and mechanical aspects of healing and functional correction. The procedure involves creating an osteotomy to realign bones (a mechanical correction) while also considering how the body will biologically heal post-surgery. This ensures that the new alignment supports the function of the joint and surrounding tissues, facilitating both the mechanical and biological processes necessary for recovery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical:

 

  • A mechanical principle in orthopedic surgery typically refers to techniques or interventions that are focused on the physical mechanics or structural alignment of the body. Mechanical principles focus on how the bones, joints, and tissues interact to bear loads, and may include concepts like forces, levers, and mechanical advantage.
  • While McMurray’s Osteotomy does address the mechanical alignment of bones, it involves more than just a purely mechanical correction. The osteotomy also considers the biological healing process, as well as the impact on surrounding tissues. This makes the mechanical principle not entirely sufficient to describe the procedure.

 

Option B. Biological:

 

  • A biological principle in orthopedics emphasizes the body’s natural healing processes and biological responses to injury or surgery. It involves concepts such as bone healing, tissue regeneration, and how the body adapts to and heals from surgical interventions.
  • McMurray’s Osteotomy isn’t based solely on biological principles. While healing and tissue regeneration are important for the success of the osteotomy, the procedure is more focused on both the mechanical alignment and the functional interaction between the skeletal structure and surrounding tissues, making it not purely biological in nature.

 

Option D. None:

 

  • This option implies that none of the above principles are applicable to McMurray's Osteotomy.
  • Since the procedure involves both mechanical and biological aspects (as explained above), "None" is not the correct choice, because the osteotomy clearly follows a biomechanical principle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • McMurray’s Osteotomy is based on the principle of biomechanics, which integrates the mechanical correction of deformities with an understanding of the biological processes necessary for healing and function.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals has a role similar to vitamin E in countering oxidative stress?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenium

 

  • Selenium is an essential trace mineral that plays a vital role in antioxidant defense. 
  • It is a critical component of glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that reduces hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides, thereby preventing oxidative damage to cells. 
  • This antioxidant action is similar to that of vitamin E, which protects cell membranes from lipid peroxidation. 
  • Together, selenium and vitamin E function synergistically to mitigate oxidative stress.
  • Selenium’s antioxidant properties make it particularly important in tissues with high oxidative metabolism, such as the heart and liver. Its deficiency can lead to conditions like Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and increased susceptibility to oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnesium: Magnesium is essential for numerous enzymatic processes, particularly those involving energy metabolism and nucleic acid synthesis. However, it does not have a direct antioxidant role and does not mimic the action of vitamin E.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium is primarily involved in processes like bone health, neurotransmitter release, and muscle contraction. It does not function as an antioxidant or have a role similar to vitamin E in mitigating oxidative stress.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron, while essential for hemoglobin synthesis and cellular respiration, can actually promote oxidative stress through the Fenton reaction, which generates free radicals. It does not act like vitamin E and, in excess, can exacerbate oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenium has an antioxidant role similar to vitamin E by being a critical component of glutathione peroxidase, which reduces hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides, protecting cells from oxidative damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with chronic vaginal itching, burning sensations, and painful intercourse. She has been diagnosed with vaginal lichen planus and is seeking effective treatments to alleviate her symptoms. Considering the challenges in managing vaginal lichen planus, which of the following treatments has been reported to provide symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal corticosteroid suppositories

 

  • Vaginal corticosteroid suppositories are the most appropriate treatment for managing vaginal lichen planus. 
  • Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the mucous membranes, leading to symptoms like itching, burning, and painful intercourse. 
  • Corticosteroids reduce local inflammation and alleviate these symptoms by suppressing the immune response. 
  • Vaginal suppositories allow for direct application to the affected area, providing targeted relief and improving the patient's quality of life. 
  • This method is preferred due to its effectiveness in managing the chronic and often refractory nature of vaginal lichen planus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minocycline: Minocycline is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections and certain inflammatory conditions, but it is not a standard treatment for lichen planus, which is primarily an autoimmune-mediated disorder. Therefore, minocycline is not appropriate for providing symptomatic relief in vaginal lichen planus.

 

Option B. Sequential vaginal dilators: Sequential vaginal dilators are used to treat vaginal stenosis or scarring, often following radiation therapy or surgery, to maintain vaginal elasticity. They do not address the inflammatory processes involved in lichen planus and thus are not effective for symptom relief in this condition.

 

Option D. Estrogen cream: Estrogen creams are used to treat vaginal atrophy, particularly in postmenopausal women, by improving vaginal mucosa health and reducing dryness and irritation. While they can help with some vaginal symptoms, they do not specifically target the inflammatory processes of lichen planus and are not the most effective treatment for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal corticosteroid suppositories are an effective treatment option for symptomatic relief in vaginal lichen planus by reducing local inflammation and alleviating symptoms such as itching, burning, and painful intercourse.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a lateral side pain on his hand. Identify the problem.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enchondroma

 

  • Enchondroma is a benign cartilage tumour that often occurs in the small bones of the hands and feet. It arises from cartilage and is usually asymptomatic, though it can cause pain if it leads to bone weakening or fracture.
  • Enchondromas are typically found in the proximal phalanx or metacarpals of the hand. They often cause pain if they grow larger and cause mechanical irritation or fracture. Pain is often localized and can be associated with activity or trauma. Enchondromas are also common in young adults, especially in the second to third decades of life
  • Enchondroma is a common cause of lateral hand pain in young adults. Its characteristic location in the small bones of the hand (such as in the metacarpals or phalanges) and its tendency to cause localized pain, especially if there’s a fracture or growth, make this the most likely diagnosis for the patient in question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giant Cell Tumour:

 

  • A giant cell tumour (GCT) is a benign tumour typically found around the ends of long bones, especially the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius. It is composed of multinucleated giant cells and is known for its locally aggressive behaviour.
  • GCT often presents as a painful, swelling mass and is more common in young adults, usually aged 20–40. However, it typically affects the epiphyses of long bones, not the hand. Giant cell tumours are often associated with bone destruction and can cause pathologic fractures.
  • Although the patient is in the age range where GCT may occur, the location of the pain is not typical for a GCT, which generally affects the ends of long bones, not the hand's lateral side. This makes GCT less likely for this presentation.

 

Option B. Osteoblastoma:

 

  • Osteoblastoma is a rare, benign bone tumour characterized by the formation of new bone tissue. It usually affects the spine and long bones but can also occur in other bones, including the hands.
  • Osteoblastomas cause localized pain, which may be worse at night The tumour is generally larger than osteoid osteomas and can lead to cortical bone expansion.
  • While osteoblastomas can cause pain in the hands, they tend to be larger and often present with more noticeable swelling or a palpable mass. Additionally, the pain in osteoblastoma tends to be more severe and deep and may not be isolated to the lateral side of the hand, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enchondroma commonly occurs in the small bones of the hand, causing localized pain, and are more common in young adults. 
  • The other options (giant cell tumour, osteoblastoma, and osteoid osteoma) are less likely due to their typical locations and clinical features.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with headache, vomiting, and unsteady gait. Imaging reveals a midline posterior fossa mass consistent with medulloblastoma. Which of the following chromosomes is most commonly associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chromosome 17

 

  • Medulloblastoma, a malignant pediatric brain tumor, is often associated with genetic mutations involving chromosome 17. 
  • The most frequent abnormality is isodicentric 17q (i(17q)), which results in the loss of genetic material from 17p and duplication of 17q. 
  • These genetic changes impact tumor suppressor genes, promoting tumor development and progression. 
  • Medulloblastomas are also linked to signaling pathway dysregulation, including WNT and SHH (Sonic Hedgehog) pathways, but chromosome 17 alterations remain a key marker.
  • This tumor commonly arises in the posterior fossa and presents with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting), as well as cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia or unsteady gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 18: Chromosome 18 mutations are not commonly associated with medulloblastoma. Instead, this chromosome is more often implicated in other malignancies, such as colorectal cancer, where mutations in the DCC gene are observed.

 

Option C. Chromosome 19: Chromosome 19 mutations are linked to other tumor types but are not characteristic of medulloblastoma.

 

Option D. Chromosome 16: Chromosome 16 is not a major site of mutations associated with medulloblastoma. It may be implicated in other conditions, such as nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor), but not in this pediatric brain tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Medulloblastoma is associated with chromosome 17 abnormalities, particularly isodicentric 17q (i(17q)), which leads to tumor suppressor gene dysregulation. 
  • This genetic change is a hallmark of this malignant pediatric brain tumor.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic heart disease was hospitalized for severe breathlessness. She passed away on the third day of admission. Autopsy of the mitral valve reveals the following findings. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and fibrosis

 

  • The findings described in the mitral valve are classic for chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD). 
  • Chronic RHD results from repeated inflammation and scarring caused by episodes of acute rheumatic fever. 
  • Over time, this leads to fibrosis, calcification, and commissural fusion of the mitral valve. These changes produce the typical "fish mouth" or "buttonhole" deformity seen in chronic RHD.
  • The valve deformity causes mitral stenosis, which increases left atrial pressure, leading to pulmonary hypertension and severe breathlessness (as seen in this patient). 
  • Mitral stenosis predisposes patients to atrial fibrillation, thromboembolic events, and heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocardial thickening: Endocardial thickening can occur in various conditions, such as endocarditis or endomyocardial fibrosis. However, the chronic scarring and calcification of the mitral valve in this case are specific to chronic rheumatic heart disease.

 

Option C. Thrombus formation: Thrombus formation in the left atrium is a complication of mitral stenosis due to stasis of blood flow. While thromboembolic events may occur secondary to mitral stenosis, thrombus formation does not cause the fibrosis and calcification observed in the mitral valve itself.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of the ventricular wall: Hypertrophy of the ventricular wall is associated with pressure overload, such as in systemic hypertension or aortic stenosis. It is not related to mitral valve fibrosis and calcification caused by chronic rheumatic heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic rheumatic heart disease is characterized by fibrosis, calcification, and commissural fusion of the mitral valve, leading to mitral stenosis. This condition results from repeated inflammation and scarring due to acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with severe asthma is not responding adequately to her current therapy of inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs). She has a high eosinophil count in her blood. Which of the following therapies would be the most appropriate for her condition as an add-on therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mepolizumab

 

  • Mepolizumab is an IL-5 antagonist that is used as an add-on therapy for patients with severe asthma, particularly those with high eosinophil counts. 
  • IL-5 plays a central role in the eosinophilic inflammation that is seen in some severe asthma patients, and targeting this cytokine can help reduce exacerbations and improve asthma control.
  • Mepolizumab is FDA-approved for severe asthma with an eosinophilic phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketotifen: Although ketotifen has antihistaminic properties and mast cell stabilizing action, it is not used as an add-on therapy for severe asthma in this context.

 

Option C. Roflumilast: Roflumilast is a PDE-4 inhibitor used in COPD to reduce inflammation but is not indicated for severe asthma.

 

Option D. Theophylline: Theophylline is an older drug that may be used for asthma but is no longer considered first-line treatment for severe asthma, especially when better therapies like Mepolizumab are available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mepolizumab is an IL-5 antagonist used as an add-on therapy for severe asthma with an eosinophilic phenotype.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of chronic dyspepsia and upper abdominal pain undergoes an endoscopy, which reveals gastric ulcers and inflammation of the gastric mucosa. Laboratory evaluation indicates elevated levels of a hormone that stimulates the secretion of hydrochloric acid. Which type of gastric mucosal cells is primarily responsible for producing this hormone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G cells

 

  • G cells are specialized enteroendocrine cells located predominantly in the antrum of the stomach. 
  • They secrete gastrin, a hormone that stimulates parietal cells in the gastric mucosa to produce hydrochloric acid (HCl). 
  • Elevated levels of gastrin can exacerbate acid-related disorders such as peptic ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) by increasing gastric acid secretion.
  • Mechanism: Gastrin binds to cholecystokinin (CCK)-B receptors on parietal cells and activates the proton pump via histamine release from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells. This leads to increased HCl secretion, contributing to the development of gastric ulcers in susceptible patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S cells: S cells are located in the duodenum and secrete secretin, which stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate and inhibits gastric acid secretion. They do not play a direct role in hydrochloric acid production or contribute to the pathophysiology of peptic ulcers.

 

Option B. Peptic cells: Peptic cells, also known as chief cells, secrete pepsinogen, which is converted to pepsin in the acidic gastric environment. While pepsin aids in protein digestion, chief cells do not produce or regulate gastric acid secretion.

 

Option D. H cells: H cells are not a recognized type of gastric mucosal cell involved in acid production or regulation. This choice is incorrect and likely included as a distractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • G cells in the gastric antrum secrete gastrin, a hormone that stimulates hydrochloric acid secretion by parietal cells, contributing to acid-related disorders such as GERD and peptic ulcer disease. 
  • Understanding the role of G cells is critical in managing conditions associated with hypergastrinemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have an occlusion of the second part of the axillary artery. However, ischemia is not observed in the upper limb due to the collateral circulation through the anastomoses of arteries around the scapula. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to this anastomosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral thoracic artery

 

  • The collateral circulation around the scapula prevents ischemia in cases of axillary artery occlusion. 
  • This anastomotic network involves several arteries, including the transverse cervical artery, suprascapular artery, and subscapular artery, which ensure adequate blood flow to the upper limb.
  • The lateral thoracic artery, on the other hand, primarily supplies the lateral chest wall and serratus anterior muscle and does not contribute significantly to the scapular anastomosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse cervical artery: This artery, a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, participates in the scapular anastomosis by supplying the trapezius and connecting with the dorsal scapular artery and subscapular artery.

 

Option C. Subscapular artery: The subscapular artery, a branch of the third part of the axillary artery, is a key component of the scapular anastomosis. It gives rise to the circumflex scapular artery, which participates in this collateral network.

 

Option D. Suprascapular artery: The suprascapular artery, also a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, contributes to the scapular anastomosis by connecting with the circumflex scapular artery and dorsal scapular artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral thoracic artery does not contribute to the scapular anastomosis, which involves the transverse cervical, suprascapular, and subscapular arteries. 
  • This anastomosis maintains blood flow to the upper limb during occlusion of the axillary artery.

questions.text: An agricultural worker is concerned about the safety of using insecticides in a field with minimal risk to human health. The worker is looking for an insecticide that is least toxic to humans but highly toxic to insects. Which of the following insecticides meets these criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malathion

 

  • Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide that is considered to be the least toxic to humans among the options listed, while still being highly toxic to insects. 
  • Its relatively low toxicity to humans is due to its rapid metabolism in the human body, which reduces its harmful effects. 
  • Malathion is commonly used in agriculture and public health for pest control with minimal risk to human health when used according to safety guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parathion: Incorrect. Parathion is also an organophosphate insecticide, but it is more toxic to humans than malathion. It has a greater potential for toxicity and is banned or restricted in many countries due to its harmful effects on human health.

 

Option C. Physostigmine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is an alkaloid and not typically used as an insecticide. It acts as an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and can be toxic to humans, though it is not an insecticide by itself.

 

Option D. Nicotine: Incorrect. While nicotine is toxic to insects, it is highly toxic to humans as well. It is not used as a common insecticide due to its high toxicity to humans, despite its effectiveness in insect control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malathion is the least toxic insecticide to humans while being highly toxic to insects, making it a safer option for pest control in agricultural and public health applications.

questions.text: A term newborn weighing 2700 grams presents with jaundice on the fifth day of life. Serum bilirubin levels are measured at 14 mg/dL. The baby is otherwise healthy and feeding well. What would be the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Routine newborn care

 

  • According to AIIMS NICU Protocol 2019, the threshold for phototherapy in an otherwise healthy term neonate on the fifth day of life is approximately 20 mg/dL. 
  • Since the bilirubin level in this neonate is only 14 mg/dL, it does not meet the criteria for phototherapy or any other specific intervention. 
  • Routine newborn care, including monitoring and breastfeeding, is sufficient for managing this neonate. 
  • No additional treatment is required unless bilirubin levels increase significantly or the baby develops concerning signs or symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phototherapy: Phototherapy is indicated only when bilirubin levels reach the treatment threshold (approximately 20 mg/dL on day 5 for a term neonate). Since the current level is well below this, phototherapy is not required.

 

Option B. Exchange transfusion: Exchange transfusion is reserved for extremely high bilirubin levels or in cases where there are signs of bilirubin toxicity or encephalopathy. This baby does not meet these criteria.

 

Option D. Stop breastfeeding for 2 days: Breastfeeding should not be stopped, as it provides essential nutrition and immunity. This approach is not recommended in the management of neonatal jaundice unless there is a clear indication of significant breastfeeding-related jaundice, which is not evident here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • In an otherwise healthy term neonate with bilirubin levels below the phototherapy threshold, routine newborn care is sufficient, and no specific intervention is required. 
  • Always use established guidelines, such as AIIMS NICU protocols or bilirubin nomograms, to guide management.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive pregnancy test, but transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Endometrial biopsy reveals hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and poor decidualization. This histological finding is consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arias-Stella reaction

 

  • The Arias-Stella reaction is a histological finding characterized by hypersecretory endometrial glands with nuclear atypia, often associated with ectopic pregnancy. 
  • This reaction occurs due to exposure of the endometrium to abnormal hormonal levels, particularly low progesterone, which leads to poor decidualization. 
  • The presence of these atypical hypersecretory changes is a key diagnostic clue when evaluating for ectopic pregnancy in a patient with a positive pregnancy test and no evidence of an intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometritis: Endometritis is characterized by infiltration of the endometrium with neutrophils or plasma cells, depending on whether the infection is acute or chronic. It does not involve the hypersecretory glandular changes or nuclear atypia seen in the Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Option C. Decidual reaction: A decidual reaction refers to the normal histological transformation of endometrial stromal cells into decidual cells during pregnancy, induced by progesterone. Unlike the Arias-Stella reaction, decidualization is associated with a well-developed and organized appearance of the endometrium, without nuclear atypia or hypersecretory changes.

 

Option D. Chronic inflammation: Chronic inflammation of the endometrium is marked by plasma cell infiltration and is typically associated with chronic infections or autoimmune conditions. It is not associated with the hypersecretory changes or nuclear atypia characteristic of the Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Arias-Stella reaction is a histological hallmark of ectopic pregnancy. 
  • It is characterized by hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and is caused by inadequate hormonal support, particularly low progesterone, leading to poor decidualization. 
  • This finding is a key diagnostic feature in patients with suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman with a history of two prior cesarean deliveries presents at 34 weeks gestation with ultrasound findings suggestive of placental invasion into the uterine myometrium. The pathology is related to the absence of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nitabuch’s layer

 

  • The accreta spectrum (which includes placenta accreta, increta, and percreta) results from abnormal placental attachment to the uterine wall due to a defect or absence of Nitabuch’s layer, a fibrinoid layer that normally separates the placenta from the decidua basalis. 
  • This defect allows the chorionic villi to directly invade the myometrium, leading to the following classifications:
    • Placenta accreta: Superficial attachment to the myometrium.
    • Placenta increta: Invasion into the myometrium.
    • Placenta percreta: Invasion through the uterine wall and possibly into adjacent organs.
  • Risk factors include prior uterine surgeries (e.g., cesarean deliveries), placenta previa, and uterine scarring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decidua basalis: The decidua basalis is the maternal portion of the placenta. A deficiency in this layer may be associated with abnormal implantation, but the absence of Nitabuch’s layer is the defining cause of the accreta spectrum.

 

Option C. Placental villi: Placental villi are the structures that invade the decidua and are normally restricted by Nitabuch’s layer. While they are involved in the pathophysiology of accreta, their abnormal invasion occurs secondary to the absence of Nitabuch’s layer.

 

Option D. Trophoblastic shell: The trophoblastic shell anchors the placenta to the decidua but does not play a direct role in the prevention of invasive placental attachment. Its function is primarily structural during normal implantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The absence or defect of Nitabuch’s layer is the primary cause of the placenta accreta spectrum, leading to abnormal placental invasion into the myometrium.

choices.text: From the medial to lateral part of the diaphragm

questions.text: The dorsal mesentery of the esophagus contributes to which of the following components of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crura

 

  • The dorsal mesentery of the esophagus contributes to the formation of the crura of the diaphragm. 
  • The crura are muscular structures that extend inferiorly from the diaphragm and attach to the lumbar vertebrae. 
  • These structures play an essential role in anchoring the diaphragm and ensuring its proper function during respiration.
  • The development of the diaphragm involves contributions from four embryological components: the septum transversum, pleuroperitoneal membranes, mesoderm of the body wall, and the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus (which forms the crura). 
  • Failure in the development or fusion of these components can lead to congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Septum transversum: The septum transversum forms the central tendon of the diaphragm. It does not contribute to the crura.

 

Option C. Pleuroperitoneal membrane: The pleuroperitoneal membranes contribute to the formation of the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm but are unrelated to the crura.

 

Option D. From the medial to lateral part of the diaphragm: This description does not correspond to any specific developmental structure of the diaphragm and is anatomically imprecise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal mesentery of the esophagus forms the crura of the diaphragm, which are essential for anchoring the diaphragm to the lumbar vertebrae.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with symptoms of periorificial dermatitis, conjunctivitis, and alopecia. The mother reports that the baby has been unusually lethargic and has had episodes of seizures. Which of the following vitamins is most likely deficient in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biotin

 

  • Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis, and amino acid metabolism.
  • A deficiency in biotin can lead to clinical features such as periorificial dermatitis, conjunctivitis, alopecia, lethargy, and seizures, as seen in the case presented.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Deficiency causes beriberi, characterized by irritability, peripheral neuritis, and cardiovascular symptoms, but it does not cause dermatitis or alopecia.

 

Option B. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin deficiency is associated with glossitis, cheilosis, keratitis, and peripheral neuropathy, but not the constellation of symptoms described here.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Pyridoxine deficiency causes seizures and microcytic anemia but does not result in alopecia or periorificial dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Biotin deficiency manifests as periorificial dermatitis, alopecia, lethargy, and seizures due to its role as a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with hematuria and fatigue for 1 week, accompanied by unintentional weight loss over the past month. On examination, he appears pale and cachectic. A non-tender right flank mass is palpated. A CT scan reveals a 5-cm right upper pole renal mass and multiple pulmonary lesions. A biopsy of a pulmonary lesion confirms the diagnosis. What genetic alteration is most commonly associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VHL gene deletion

 

  • The patient’s clinical presentation, imaging findings, and histopathology are consistent with renal cell carcinoma (RCC), specifically clear cell carcinoma. 
  • This is the most common subtype of RCC and is strongly associated with deletion or inactivation of the VHL (von Hippel-Lindau) tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p. 
  • Loss of VHL function leads to increased activity of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIF), driving angiogenesis and tumor growth.

 

Other Options:


Option A. NF1 gene inactivation: Incorrect, NF1 gene inactivation is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, which predisposes to different tumor types, including pheochromocytomas and optic gliomas, but not RCC.

 

Option B. PKD1 gene mutation: Incorrect, PKD1 gene mutations are associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which does not directly cause renal cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. MYCL1 amplification: Incorrect: MYCL1 amplification is associated with small cell lung cancer, not RCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • VHL gene deletion is a hallmark genetic alteration in clear cell renal cell carcinoma, leading to dysregulated angiogenesis and tumor progression. 
  • Early recognition and appropriate management, including systemic therapy for metastatic lesions, are essential.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of osteoarthritis presents to your clinic for follow-up. She is currently taking several medications, including a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for pain relief. You explain to her that some medications work by irreversibly interacting with their target, leading to prolonged effects. Which of the following drugs achieves this irreversible effect through a covalent bond with its target?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspirin

 

  • Aspirin, a well-known NSAID, works by irreversibly inhibiting the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is involved in the synthesis of prostaglandins. 
  • It achieves this by covalently binding to a serine residue in the active site of the enzyme, leading to prolonged inhibition. The covalent binding means that the effects of aspirin last longer than the drug's presence in the bloodstream. 
  • This irreversible interaction is what differentiates aspirin from other drugs that exhibit reversible binding to their targets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillin: Penicillin binds covalently to bacterial transpeptidase enzymes, which are involved in cell wall synthesis, but this binding does not typically result in the long-lasting effects associated with drugs like aspirin. Penicillin's covalent interaction is effective for bacterial cell wall destruction, but it does not lead to prolonged drug action after the drug is cleared.

 

Option C. Nitric oxide: Nitric oxide is a gaseous molecule that activates the enzyme guanylate cyclase to increase cyclic GMP production, leading to smooth muscle relaxation. This action is not mediated by covalent binding. Nitric oxide exerts its effects through reversible, non-covalent interactions with its target enzyme.

 

Option D. Bosentan: Bosentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. It works by binding to endothelin receptors to prevent vasoconstriction but does so via a reversible, non-covalent interaction, unlike the irreversible binding seen with aspirin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) by covalently binding to it, resulting in prolonged effects on prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with resting tremors, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. These symptoms are attributed to degeneration of neurons in a specific neural pathway connecting the substantia nigra to the striatum. The neurotransmitter primarily involved in this pathway is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dopamine

 

  • The nigrostriatal pathway is a major dopaminergic tract in the brain, comprising neurons that project from the substantia nigra pars compacta to the dorsal striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). 
  • This pathway plays a critical role in regulating movement. 
  • Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in this pathway leads to dopamine deficiency in the striatum, resulting in the hallmark motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as resting tremors, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is involved in various neural pathways. However, it is not the main neurotransmitter in the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option B. GABA: GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. While GABAergic neurons are present in the basal ganglia, they are not the primary neurotransmitters of the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine functions as a neurotransmitter in both the central and peripheral nervous systems, including roles in the autonomic nervous system and neuromuscular junctions. It is not the primary neurotransmitter of the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nigrostriatal pathway, connecting the substantia nigra to the striatum, primarily utilizes dopamine as its neurotransmitter. 
  • Degeneration of this pathway's dopaminergic neurons is a key factor in the development of Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A female patient with bipolar disorder becomes pregnant. She has been well-controlled on valproate for 3 years. Which medication switch carries the lowest risk of teratogenicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antipsychotics

 

  • For a pregnant woman with bipolar disorder, the lowest-risk medication in terms of teratogenicity is antipsychotics, specifically second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs). 
  • SGAs such as quetiapine, olanzapine, or aripiprazole are commonly used in pregnancy for both acute mood stabilization and maintenance therapy due to their favorable safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lithium: Lithium is effective for bipolar disorder, particularly in manic episodes and maintenance. However, it carries a small but significant risk of Ebstein’s anomaly when used during the first trimester. Close monitoring of serum levels is also necessary due to changes in renal clearance during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is associated with neural tube defects and other malformations, making it less safe than antipsychotics during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is relatively safe during pregnancy, with a low risk of teratogenicity (e.g., oral clefts), but it is primarily effective for bipolar depression rather than mania or maintenance.

 

Antipsychotics Are Preferred:

 

  • SGAs have minimal teratogenic risk compared to mood stabilizers like valproate, carbamazepine, and lithium.
  • They are effective for both manic and depressive episodes and for maintenance therapy.
  • They are widely used for mood stabilization in pregnant women with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For pregnant patients with bipolar disorder, second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs) offer the best balance of efficacy and safety, particularly for acute mania or maintenance. 
  • Lamotrigine is an alternative for patients with predominant depressive symptoms but is not as broadly effective for mania or mixed episodes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman undergoing laparoscopic surgery requires vessel sealing during the procedure. The surgeon uses an instrument shown in the image below for sealing and cutting tissues effectively, ensuring minimal thermal spread to surrounding tissues. Which of the following instruments is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Advanced bipolar

 

  • Advanced bipolar is a vessel-sealing device that uses bipolar electrosurgical energy and pressure to seal vessels and tissues up to 7 mm in diameter. 
  • The two prongs at the tip are identical. 
  • It is commonly used in laparoscopic and open surgeries for hemostasis. 
  • The device ensures minimal thermal spread and creates permanent seals by denaturing collagen and elastin in the vessel walls. 
  • The two prongs at the tip are identical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Harmonic scalpel: This device uses ultrasonic vibrations for cutting and coagulating tissues, with less thermal spread than traditional electrocautery. However, it differs in appearance and mechanism from Bipolar. The tip has one active blade and one insulated tip.

 

 

Option C. Laser fibre: It is used in ablation of varicose veins or hemorrhoids.

 

Option D. Monopolar electrocautery: This tool uses a single active electrode to cut or coagulate tissue, requiring a grounding pad for the return current. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Advanced bipolar is a vessel-sealing device that ensures hemostasis during surgical procedures by sealing vessels up to 7 mm in diameter with minimal thermal spread, making it an efficient and safe option for modern surgeries.
